title: Transformation
narrative_instruction: Use third person limited perspective, past tense. Present the Omega duckling's transformation as a mysterious, emotionally charged moment, focusing on sensory details and internal feelings. Since this is the reader's first contact with the protagonist, avoid assuming prior reader knowledge—describe the transformed being in ways that provoke curiosity, withholding backstory details.
transition_hint: Open with vivid imagery of spring and the protagonist's awakening, lingering on the sense of unfamiliarity and awe, to create intrigue and set up the need for explanation.

title: Outcast in the Nest
narrative_instruction: Continue third person limited, past tense. Shift to an extended flashback, focusing on the emotional distance between the Omega duckling and its family. Use sensory and emotional cues to show rejection and isolation, maintaining the protagonist's internal perspective.
transition_hint: Transition with a reflective passage, e.g., 'But it had not always been this way...' to signal a move into the protagonist's memories.

title: A Strange Arrival
narrative_instruction: Maintain third person limited, past tense. Continue the flashback, now detailing the protagonist's birth among Alpha and Beta siblings. Focus on immediate differences—appearance, scent, reactions of others. The protagonist observes but does not understand the implications.
transition_hint: Use a memory trigger in Chapter 2 (e.g., a taunt or exclusion) to lead naturally into the memory of first arrival and birth.

title: A Winter Alone
narrative_instruction: Stay in third person limited, past tense. Return from flashback to the protagonist's subjective experience enduring winter after rejection. Emphasize internal monologue and growing strength through adversity. Reference earlier hardships as background knowledge.
transition_hint: Conclude the flashback with a sensory anchor (e.g., the cold wind), then match that anchor to the present, signaling the passage of time and return to the current narrative.

title: Seeking Shelter
narrative_instruction: Continue third person limited, past tense. Move forward sequentially, following the protagonist's search for belonging. Emphasize encounters with unfamiliar environments and characters, with the protagonist as an outsider throughout.
transition_hint: Use the closing of winter and a change in setting or weather to mark the protagonist's movement from endurance to active searching.

title: Encounters with Others
narrative_instruction: Maintain third person limited, past tense. Chronicle the protagonist's repeated attempts to fit in, met with shunning or pity from Alphas and Betas. Focus on internal confusion and the cumulative effect on self-perception.
transition_hint: Transition with a moment of hope at the end of Chapter 3, immediately dashed by unkind or indifferent treatment in new encounters.

title: Accepted at Last
narrative_instruction: Keep third person limited, past tense. The protagonist, now a swan, is welcomed by fellow Omegas. Portray the gradual development of trust and recognition, showing the protagonist's wariness giving way to relief and joy.
transition_hint: Use the protagonist's despair at the end of Chapter 4 as a contrast to the warmth and open acceptance in this chapter, signaling emotional resolution.

title: A New Beginning
narrative_instruction: Continue third person limited, past tense. Show the protagonist's full integration and celebration of Omega identity, focusing on new friendships and inner peace. Use reflective passages to tie back to the opening transformation and hardships overcome.
transition_hint: Begin with a moment of quiet contentment after acceptance, then expand to scenes of joyful new beginnings.
